title: 114_hr4783
content: The Act titled "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022, along with administrative funding. Required expenditure amounts are also specified. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for SBIR and STTR programs from fiscal year 2018 to 2022 and each fiscal year thereafter. The Small Business Act is amended to require specific expenditure percentages for SBIR and STTR programs from fiscal year 2018 onwards, with increments each year until reaching 0.60 percent in fiscal year 2022 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to require specific expenditure percentages for SBIR and STTR programs from fiscal year 2018 onwards, with increments each year until reaching 0.60 percent in fiscal year 2022 and beyond. Reporting requirements are outlined in Section 4. The Small Business Act is amended to require annual reports to be submitted by specific deadlines, with detailed instructions on the content to be included in the reports. The Small Business Act is amended to require agencies to submit simplified and standardized reports by March 30 of each year, detailing specific instances as outlined in the legislation. The Small Business Act is amended to require agencies to submit reports by specific deadlines each year, detailing certain instances as outlined in the legislation. The Small Business Act is amended to require Federal agencies to submit reports by March 30 each year detailing the use of administrative funds authorized for the fiscal year. Failure to submit the report will result in the agency being exempt from fund authorization until the report is submitted. Federal agencies must submit reports by March 30 each year detailing the use of administrative funds. Failure to submit the report will exempt the agency from fund authorization until the report is submitted. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to adjust awards for inflation in Phase I and Phase II of SBIR or STTR programs. Phase I awards are capped at $150,000, and Phase II awards are also adjusted. Phase I awards for SBIR or STTR programs are capped at $150,000, while Phase II awards may not exceed $1,000,000. The Administrator will adjust these amounts for inflation in accordance with section 1908 of title 41, United States Code. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act to change authorization to requirement. SEC. 7 clarifies eligibility for certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility for certain small businesses under the SBIR and STTR programs. The Administrator is required to modify policy directives to ensure that small business concerns described in specific subparagraphs are eligible to receive awards. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility for certain small businesses under the SBIR and STTR programs by modifying policy directives to include specific subparagraphs for eligibility. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program, requiring covered agencies to implement a program to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award. The program should not exceed 5 percent of the agency's total SBIR funds. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires covered agencies to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award, not exceeding 5 percent of the agency's total SBIR funds. The program terminates on September 30, 2022 and includes a matching requirement for eligible third-party investors. Under a commercialization assistance pilot program, a matching amount equal to the award must be provided by an eligible third-party investor. Ineligible funding sources cannot be used for the matching requirement. Awards under this program cannot exceed certain limitations and will be distributed during the Phase II award period. To receive a second sequential SBIR award, eligible entities must submit an application. The commercialization assistance pilot program requires a matching amount from a third-party investor, with funds to be used for research and development activities that accelerate commercialization. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a second sequential SBIR award under the program. Recipients are determined by the head of the covered agency. The commercialization assistance pilot program accelerates commercialization through research and development activities. Recipients are determined based on the potential impact on commercializing research, technical feasibility, improvements to the commercialization plan, and satisfactory progress in Phase II activities. The Phase II commercialization plan aims to improve research conversion for societal benefits. Evaluation criteria include progress in Phase II activities, third-party funding expectations, and the likelihood of commercial and societal benefits. An evaluation report is due within 3 years of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016 enactment, summarizing pilot program activities. The evaluative report for commercialization assistance pilot programs includes a summary of activities, results achieved, commercialization rates, growth in employment and revenue, comparison of success with non-matching Phase II recipients, and demographic information of participant companies. The evaluative report for commercialization assistance pilot programs includes a comparison of commercialization success between pilot program participants and non-matching Phase II recipients, demographic information of participant companies, an account of funds used at each participating agency, distribution of third-party funding sources, analysis of program effectiveness at each agency, and recommendations for program improvement if made permanent. Definitions for the SBIR program include terms like 'covered agency' referring to Federal agencies with SBIR programs, 'eligible entity' for small businesses with Phase II awards, 'eligible third-party investors' for various types of investors, and 'ineligible sources' like internal R&D funds. The term 'ineligible sources' refers to funding sources that are not allowed for SBIR awards, such as internal R&D funds, non-cash funding, funding from owners or affiliates, and debt-obtained funding. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to increase underserved population participation by removing a waiver. Federal agencies must use funds to carry out a policy directive and increase participation in States with historically low SBIR awards. A conforming amendment removes the waiver authority under certain conditions.
